Description: Teacups come in a  variety of sizes and range in shape from hemispherical to cylindrical (Costello et. al 2001:36).
A bowl used for small portions of food or side dishes (Simpson et al. 1980:83).
Some researchers refer to these as rice/soup bowls because they could be used for either food (Bibb 2013:[10]; Costello et. al 2001:34).
Bowl lids are shallow bowls that sit inside rice/soup bowl rims (Gorham 1971:185, 193).
Used when a more specific chawan form cannot be determined.
A small cup for soba noodle sauce with a flat bottom and straight walls (Costello et. al 2001:36).
A large, deep bowl used for soup or don (Costello et. al 2001:35; Simpson et al. 1980:83).
Kozara are used to hold small portions of specialty foods. They sometimes have lids (Ross 2012:10).
A nakazara is a shallow dish or plate with rim diameters between about 18 and 21 cm (Ross 2012:10; Simpson et al. 2014:87).
A larger serving dish with a shallow hollow profile (Simpson et al. 2014:87,90).
Mamezari are very small dishes for condiments or sweets (Walter 2012:128).
Used for pickled vegetables, namasu-zara are a deep dishes with a large footring (Bibb 2013:[4]).
General term for a dish/plate of an indeterminate size.
These are smaller teapots designed for individual use that have a projecting side handle (Ross 2012:12).
Dobin are larger teapots with a detachable top handle used to serve tea at family meals (Cort 2000:230-231).
A teapot for which a type/function could not be determined.
Many larger sake cups are within the size range for teacups and can be used for either beverage; ochoko are exclusively for sake (Leland E. Bibb 2015, elec. comm.).
Guinomi sizes and shapes are variable but they generally have thin walls and often have everted rims (Ross 2012:10). The largest guinomi can overlap in size with smaller teacups.
General term for a sake cup of indeterminate size/function.
A kampin tokkuri is a decanter used to heat and serve sake that has a round body and tall neck (Cort 2000:231, 210).
A tall, slender decanter used for heating and serving 'thick, unrefined sake' (Cort 2000:231).
General term for a sake decanter of indeterminate size/function.
